content: I have a theorem that doesn't directly use sorry, but has the declaration uses 'sorry' warning. Is there an easy way to find which theorem invocation from the body is responsible for introducing the sorry usage?
Can you #print your_decl and Ctrl + F sorryAx in the infoview to find it in the output?
Possibly you will need set_option pp.all true in before the #print
thanks - that worked, thought I needed to increase pp.maxSteps and search through the lake build output
I may try to write a #find_sorries command to do this in a nicer way

@Aaron Hill Every sorry should either explicitly appear as a sorry in the source code or have an associated error message. Could you please say a bit about how this sorry is indirectly appearing?

If you write theorem A containing a sorry, and then reference theorem A from theorem B, you'll get 'declaration contains sorry' on theorem B. However, nothing directly indicates that the sorry is happening as a result of theorem A
When you say theorem A contains a sorry, do you mean specifically that the theorem statement contains a sorry, or do you have a case where the body of A contains a sorry that somehow leaks?
I can double-check later to make sure it wasn't also occurring in the theorem statement
NB this is not my experience in FLT, or else pretty much every statement in the repo right now would be being flagged as containing a sorry.
